TF023073-PHRD-AGRICULTURAL REFORM IMPLE. SUPPORT,TF023660-DUTCH CTF FOR EASTERN EUROPE,TF034588-RUSSIA - AGRICULTURE AND LAND

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was
            substantial, and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory,. The lessons learned indicate that the
            greatest successes of Land Reform Implementation Support
            (LARIS) came about through a well designed and delivered
            training program, much of it abroad, that gave highly
            qualified experts insights into the practices in modern
            systems, procedures and technologies used in successful
            economies. The institutional structures for the registration
            of property rights are more complicated now than they were
            when the Project started and transactions are, as a result,
            more difficult and expensive. In the first three years
            following Board approval, there were many problems relating
            to fundamental issues of institutional responsibility, law,
            land policy, government counterpart funding, slow
            procurement and sub-loan agreements with Subjects of the
            Federation. Requirements for participation of regions in
            projects need to be spelled out and agreed prior to Board
            presentation. Practical solutions need to be found to the
            procurement of complex information systems for Bank
            projects. When working at a headquarters and planning it is
            necessary to make some assumptions, but when actually
            purchasing it is necessary to make visits, assess the
            situation and wish-list of the local offices and then make
            judgments accordingly. The impact of an efficient and
            equitable cadastre system for land taxes has a huge and
            fundamental benefit. Having multiple agencies responsible
            for various aspects of transactions in land and real estate
            is inefficient and creates problems, expense and time delays
            for market participants, thus discouraging economic development.
